Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Robust and Low-Cost Smart Skin with Active Sensing Network for Enhancing Human-Robot Interaction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tactile sensing is ubiquitous in nature - arguably even more essential than vision. Most animals have thousands of cutaneous sensors over their bodies for touch, temperature, etc. But even the most sophisticated robots have relatively few tactile sensors and, after 30 years of research, tactile sensing lags behind computer vision. This project aims at the development of a novel artificial skin mimicking the human skin that can be fitted into any robotic hand providing information-rich "sense of touch." This technology leads to the development of extremely sensitive robotic skins with unprecedented tactile sensing capabilities. As such, this work enables a plethora of robotic applications where tactile sensing is of utmost importance, ranging from robotic caregivers to medical robotics and autonomous exploration. The methodology in this project may revolutionize the way future robots are designed enabling their broad applicability. This effort represents a major milestone in endowing robots with the sensory information required to carry out tasks in human-centered environments.

The advent of microprocessors for touch sensing, spurred by the smart phone industry, has helped to address the wiring problem with local processing of information and communication. However, there remain the critical problems of fabricating a multi-functional artificial skin that can conformally cover arbitrary surfaces, diagnosing in real-time, the contact state, and gathering a large amount of data for high-resolution tactile sensing, while minimizing power consumption. Overall, this effort addresses tactile sensing from a system-level point of view. The approach involves the development of advanced manufacturing technologies from leveraging nonstandard CMOS/MEMS/NEMS fabrication processes to produce a low-cost and robust artificial skin outfitted with multi-modal micro-sensors. The tactile sense of touch is achieved via an innovative micro-contact sensing technique based on ultrasound waves generated from embedded sensors to identify local contact/slip conditions. Finally, the validation and performance evaluation is demonstrated through a series of graded tactile sensing experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tactile sensing is ubiquitous in nature - arguably even more basic and essential than vision. Most animals have thousands of cutaneous sensors over their bodies for touch, temperature, etc. This haptic perception, if added to robots, can significantly enhance their performance through better human-robot and robot-environment interactions. In comparison, even the most sophisticated robots have at most a few dozen tactile sensors. Regardless of over thirty years of research, tactile sensing still falls behind progress in computer vision methods. The reason for this discrepancy is that compared to cameras, tactile sensors must be compliant, tough and flexible enough to cover the surfaces of robotic limbs and hands. In addition, as the number of sensors increases, wiring and signal transfer become a major issue.

To overcome the challenges for robotic tactile sensing, Stanford Structures and Composites Laboratory (SACL) has been working on a novel self-sensing "smart" glove based on an artificial skin that mimics the human skin and can be fitted into any robotic hand providing high-resolution, information-rich "sense of touch". This work will enable a plethora of robotic applications where tactile sensing is of utmost importance, ranging from robotic caregivers to medical robotics and autonomous exploration.

Specifically, the research outcomes of the work are the following:

Outcome 1: Stretchable Sensor Network Design Optimization for Deployment on Robotic Skin: The major effort was focused on designing an island-bridge stretchable device for bi-directional stretching. That, upon stretching, will have its islands located at pre-determined positions. A technique was developed for high spatial accuracy design of island-bridge layout flexible electronics. The technique consists of interconnected local and global level design stages. In the global level, a surrogate large-scale modeling technique and a solution scheme for determination of optimum bridge configuration is introduced. In the local level, optimized parameters from the global model are solved for fabrication-ready designs with the inclusion of micro-fabrication and geometrical constraints. This interconnected modeling technique is implemented into a fully functional in-house developed software "AccuStretch". As computational validation, a smaller scale design is studied resulting in a very close match between the target, surrogate model, and detailed model locations.

Outcome 2: Advanced Microfabrication Techniques for "Smart" Skins: A stretchable sensor network with high signal-to-noise ratio and measurement accuracy was designed for real-time distributed sensing and remote monitoring. A recyclable microfabrication process flow was developed to improve the yield and efficiency of the sensor network production. The sensor network consists of a total of 17 sensors in a 5 by 11 nodal network for impact, strain, and temperature sensing. The sensor network was successfully deployed with an in-house stretch machine to expand it from millimeter to meter scale automatically. The stretched network was integrated with a flexible frame with edge-mount electronics for signal conditioning, processing, power, and wireless communication capabilities. The stretchable sensors comprising electronic circuits can be integrated on unconventional surfaces for practical applications. The current research demonstrated the design, fabrication, and integration of sensor networks on a composite 3-D structure.

Outcome 3: Active Slip/Contact Detection Sensors Using Embedded Piezoelectric Wafer Sensors: We developed an active tactile sensing method using ultrasound waves generated from embedded piezoelectric sensors to detect and diagnose local contact/slip conditions. Robotic finger geometry and substrate materials were investigated to improve the sensitivity of this transduction mechanism. Leveraging the knowledge from this investigation, we then designed and fabricated a robotic skin which can fit for the geometry of a robotic finger. This skin demonstrated large mechanical deformation under shear load over the contact area which facilitates its interaction with ultrasound guided wave propagation in the fingertip. By analyzing the sensed signals using the proposed tactile index (TI), we found that the TI trend demonstrates great sensitivity and can be used as an indicator for early slip detection.

In addition, an electromechanical impedance-based method was applied to investigate the response of piezoelectric sensors to the static normal pressure load. The smart skin sample was firstly fabricated by embedding piezoelectric sensor into the soft silicone. Then, a series of static pressure tests to the skin were conducted. Test results showed that the first peak of the real part impedance signal was sensitive to static pressure load, and by using the proposed diagnostic method, this test setup could detect a resolution of 0.5 N force. A numerical simulation was then performed to verify the change of the impedance response in the experiment, which is closely related to the stiffness change of the silicone rubber due to load effects.
